p: Guillain-Barr√© syndrome (GBS) is an acute inflammatory immune-mediated polyradiculoneuropathy presenting classically with ascending progressive weakness, sensory changes, and hyporeflexia [ 1]. It is the most common cause of acute flaccid paralysis worldwide [ 1, 2]. GBS is usually precipitated by a preceding infection or other antigenic stimuli [ 3]. One of the pathophysiological mechanisms linked to GBS is molecular mimicry, as some pathogens may have antigens similar to peripheral nerve myelin and/or axonal epitopes [ 1, 2, 4]. The most commonly identified triggering agents are Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae [ 1, 2, 4].
